docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN legislation making it easier for the United States to enter new free-trade agreements was passed last summer, reactions were black and white. President Bush called the trade promotion authority bill, formerly known as ''fast track,'' ''a victory for the American economy'' and dreamed aloud of free trade pacts with Chile, Singapore, Australia and Morocco, the nations of southern Africa and the democracies of the Western Hemisphere. The President sees trade as a means of increasing exports and creating more than enough jobs to compensate for those that will inevitably be lost to foreign imports.

headline.main: Global Trade in Elmwood Park: Familiar Saga With a Twist

docs.abstract: Article on impact of free trade accords on labor market within United States; Pres Bush sees free trade as means of increasing exports and creating more than enough jobs to compensate for those that will inevitably be lost to foreign imports; unions doubt that; AFL-CIO president John J Sweeney calls free-trade agreements 'blank check' to send good jobs overseas; picture from Elmwood Park, NJ, is mixed after JVC Corp closes its plant to move it overseas and Marcal Paper Mills takes over site to expand its business; photos (Special Section, Working) (M)
